spanishExample: Si tuviera más amigos, no estaría tan mal.
englishTranslation: If she had more friends, she wouldn’t be so unwell.
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)
tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: Si tuviera tiempo, *I would study* más.
englishTranslation: If I had time, I would study more.

spanishExample: ¡Ten los dos y vámonos!
englishTranslation: Have both of them and let’s leave!

spanishExample: ¡Vamos otra vez ya que tenemos mucho tiempo!
englishTranslation: Let’s go again since we have a lot of time!
vocabIncluded: ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: ¡Váyanse! Fuimos amigos una vez, pero ya no lo somos.
englishTranslation: (All of you) Leave! We were friends once, but we aren’t anymore.
vocabIncluded: lo: "that way", "like that", constructed like a direct object (esp with Ser and Estar)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: ¡Váyase! ¡No lo *want to see* para nada!
englishTranslation: Leave! I don’t want to see you (formal, masculine) at all!

spanishExample: ¡Vete! Tu *presence* aquí está de más.
englishTranslation: Leave! Your presence here is extra.

spanishExample: Ella *came* para que usted fuera.
englishTranslation: She came in order for you (formal) to go.
vocabIncluded: usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Estarían *happy* si ella fuera con ellos.
englishTranslation: They would be happy if she went with them.
vocabIncluded: estarían: "would be", "they would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Fui el *winner* ese día.
englishTranslation: I was the winner that day.

spanishExample: Fuiste mi mejor amigo en el *camp.*
englishTranslation: You were my best friend at camp.

spanishExample: *He wanted* que fuera su amigo.
englishTranslation: He wanted me to be his friend.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I saw* a otra chica en vez.
englishTranslation: I saw another girl instead.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: *I wanted* que usted tuviera una buena vida.
englishTranslation: I wanted you (formal) to have a good life.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: No está de más tener tres en vez de dos.
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt to have three instead of two.
vocabIncluded: no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: Si él estuviera aquí, uno no lo tendría que hacer.
englishTranslation: If he were here, one wouldn’t have to do it.
vocabIncluded: tendría: "would have", "he/she/it would have" (Tener, conditional, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Si yo fuera tú, iría. ¡Ve!
englishTranslation: If I were you, I would go. Go!
vocabIncluded: iría: "would go", "I would go" (Ir, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: *They recommended* que estuviera en casa.
englishTranslation: They recommended that she be at home.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *They wanted* que yo estuviera en *the cinema.*
englishTranslation: They wanted me to be at the cinema.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *They wanted* que yo fuera lo que ellos fueron esa vez.
englishTranslation: They wanted me to be what they were that time.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Uno tiene que estar en *a city* que tiene de todo.
englishTranslation: One has to be in a city that has a bit of everything.
vocabIncluded: tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
